Package com.hiddenswitch.spellsource.util

Interface RpcClient<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The service class proxied.
    public interface RpcClient<T>
    A remote procedure call client. Its methods, sync(), uncheckedSync() and async(Handler) provides three different convenient ways for you to make calls to other microservices using the same interface RpcClient.

    Internally, this is proxy of a Vertx event bus communicating service.

    • Method Detail

      • async

        default <R> T async​(io.vertx.core.Handler<io.vertx.core.AsyncResult<R>> handler)
        Make an RPC call with an idiomatically asynchronous coding convention, like what you would expect in Node.

        You CANNOT reuse this proxy for more than one method call. You must always call async(Handler) for subsequent usage of the proxy.

        As an example: 

             
     // Notice that unusually, the handler comes before the actual method call, and accepts any type as its
 argument.
     accounts.async((AsyncResult<UserRecord> response) -> {
          // The handler. Do something with the response.
          if (response.failed()
          || response.result() == null) {
              resultHandler.handle(Future.failedFuture(response.cause()));
              return;
          }
          resultHandler.handle(Future.succeededFuture(response.result()));
     }).getWithToken(authInfo.getString("token"));

        Use async(Handler) in contexts like a conventional Handler which isn't running in a Fiber. Otherwise, you're strongly encouraged to use sync(), which is idiomatically cleaner.

        Internally, this retrieves a proxy of the service configured for async calls. Pass the handler for the result first. The methods called on the proxy will not return their values, they will return null. The call will go across the EventBus and arrive to your handler.

        Type Parameters:
        R - The return type of the method you will call on the proxy. This is typically a Response object.
        Parameters:
        handler - The handler of the async call. Fully specify the handler to get the right type for the method you subsequently call on the proxy.
        Returns:
        A proxy whose methods will return null.

      • promise

        default <Res> io.vertx.core.Promise<Res> promise​(SuspendableFunction<T,​Res> callHere)
        Calls the async(Handler) idiom to return a promise.
        Type Parameters:
        Res - The response type of the method to call.
        Parameters:
        callHere - A place to actually call the service. Should return the response type you desire.
        Returns:
        A Future whose completer is passed to async(Handler)

      • async

        <R> T async​(io.vertx.core.Handler<io.vertx.core.AsyncResult<R>> handler,
            long timeout)
        Executes async(Handler) with the specified timeout.
        Type Parameters:
        R - The result time.
        Parameters:
        handler - A handler for this function,.
        timeout - The timeout, in milliseconds, until no reply is assuemed.
        Returns:
        A proxy whose methods will return null.
        See Also:
        for more complete documentation.

      • sync

        @Suspendable
T sync()
throws co.paralleluniverse.fibers.SuspendExecution,
       java.lang.InterruptedException
        Gets ready to make an idiomatically synchronous (in the sense of Fiber) call to an API.

        Internally, retrieves a proxy of the service configured for Fibers "sync" calls. You must be inside a Fiber (e.g., a handler wrapped in Sync.suspendableHandler(SuspendableAction1)) to use this proxy. The methods called on the proxy will return their values, even though the call with go across the event bus.

        You can reuse this proxy for more than one sync method call.

        Returns:
        {T} A proxy whose methods will return the actual values.
        Throws:
        co.paralleluniverse.fibers.SuspendExecution
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • sync

        T sync​(java.lang.String deploymentId)
throws co.paralleluniverse.fibers.SuspendExecution,
       java.lang.InterruptedException,
       java.util.NoSuchElementException
        Gets ready to make an idiomatically synchronous (in the sense of Fiber) call to an API as served by a specific instance.

        Internally, retrieves a proxy of the service configured for Fibers "sync" calls. You must be inside a Fiber (e.g., a handler wrapped in Sync.suspendableHandler(SuspendableAction1)) to use this proxy. The methods called on the proxy will return their values, even though the call with go across the event bus.

        You can reuse this proxy for more than one sync method call.

        The function throws a checked exception if the specified deployment is not found.

        Parameters:
        deploymentId - The deployment ID of the instance to try to navigate this request to.
        Returns:
        {T} A proxy whose methods will return the actual values.
        Throws:
        co.paralleluniverse.fibers.SuspendExecution
        java.lang.InterruptedException
        java.util.NoSuchElementException

      • uncheckedSync

        @Suspendable
T uncheckedSync()
        Gets ready to make an idiomatically synchronous (in the sense of Fiber) call to an API. Does not throw SuspendExecution, so it can be used in code that is known to be running in a Fiber but not enforced to be.

        Internally, retrieves a proxy of the service configured for Fibers "sync" calls. You must be inside a Fiber (e.g., a handler wrapped in Sync.suspendableHandler(SuspendableAction1)) to use this proxy. The methods called on the proxy will return their values, even though the call with go across EventBus.

        You can reuse this proxy for more than one sync method call.

        Returns:
        {T} A proxy whose methods will return the actual values.
